001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools;
007
008/**
009 * Various utility methods for working with colors encoded as packed floats in any of the formats this can use.
010 * <br>
011 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 12/2/2019.
012 */
013public class FloatColors {
014
015    /**
016     * Converts a packed float in HSLA format (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha) to a packed float in RGBA format.
017     * @param hsla an HSLA-format packed float
018     * @return an RGBA-format packed float
019     */
020    public static float hsl2rgb(final float hsla) {
021        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(hsla);
022        return hsl2rgb((decoded & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 24 & 0xFE) / 255f);
023    }
024
025    /**
026     * Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in RGBA format.
027     * @param h hue, from 0.0 to 1.0
028     * @param s saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
029     * @param l lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
030     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
031     * @return an RGBA-format packed float
032     */
033    public static float hsl2rgb(final float h, final float s, final float l, final float a){
034        float x = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(h * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f), y = h + (2f / 3f), z = h + (1f / 3f);
035        y -= (int)y;
036        z -= (int)z;
037        y = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(y * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
038        z = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(z * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
039        float v = (l + s * Math.min(l, 1f - l));
040        float d = 2f * (1f - l / (v + 1e-10f));
041        return Color.toFloatBits(v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, x, d), v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, y, d), v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, z, d), a);
042    }
043
044    /**
045     * Converts a packed float in RGBA format to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha),
046     * which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for conversions.
047     * @param rgba an RGBA-format packed float
048     * @return an "HSLA-format" packed float
049     */
050    public static float rgb2hsl(final float rgba) {
051        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(rgba);
052        return rgb2hsl((decoded & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 24 & 0xFE) / 255f);
053    }
054
055    /**
056     * Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue,
057     * saturation, lightness, alpha), which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for
058     * conversions.
059     * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0
060     * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0
061     * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
062     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
063     * @return an "HSLA-format" packed float
064     */
065    public static float rgb2hsl(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
066        float x, y, z, w;
067        if(g < b) {
068            x = b;
069            y = g;
070            z = -1f;
071            w = 2f / 3f;
072        }
073        else {
074            x = g;
075            y = b;
076            z = 0f;
077            w = -1f / 3f;
078        }
079        if(r < x) {
080            z = w;
081            w = r;
082        }
083        else {
084            w = x;
085            x = r;
086        }
087        float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
088        float l = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
089        return Color.toFloatBits(Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)), (x - l) / (Math.min(l, 1f - l) + 1e-10f), l, a);
090    }
091
092
093    /**
094     * Given a color stored as a packed float and an alpha multiplier to affect that color (between 0f and 1f, inclusive
095     * and clamped in that range), this makes a packed float color that has the same red, green, and blue channels but
096     * has its own alpha multiplied by {@code alpha}, without constructing any objects along the way. If you want to set
097     * the alpha without considering its current value, you can use {@link #setAlpha(float, float)}
098     *
099     * @param encodedColor a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
100     *                     or {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
101     * @param alpha  between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to multiply the color's own alpha by
102     * @return a color encoded as a packed float, using color's RGB channels but with its A channel times {@code alpha}
103     */
104    public static float multiplyAlpha(final float encodedColor, final float alpha) {
105        final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encodedColor);
106        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(bits & 0xFFFFFF
107                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) ((bits >>> 24) * alpha), 0), 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
108    }
109
110    /**
111     * Given a color stored as a packed float, and a desired alpha to set for that color (between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive
112     * and clamped in that range), this makes a new float that has the same red, green, and blue channels but has been
113     * set to the given alpha, without constructing any objects along the way. This does not consider the current alpha
114     * of the encoded color; if you want to do that, you can use {@link #multiplyAlpha(float, float)}.
115     *
116     * @param encodedColor a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
117     *                     or {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
118     * @param alpha        between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to set into the returned packed color
119     * @return another color encoded as a packed float, using encodedColor's RGB channels and the given alpha
120     */
121    public static float setAlpha(final float encodedColor, final float alpha) {
122        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encodedColor) & 0xFFFFFF
123                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (255f * alpha), 0), 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
124    }
125
126    /**
127     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
128     * as from {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} or
129     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be
130     * between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is, both
131     * could be produced using Oklab, both could be produced using IPT, or both could be libGDX-native RGB, but they
132     * can't mix. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
133     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
134     * @param end the target color as a packed float
135     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
136     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
137     */
138    public static float lerpFloatColors(final float start, final float end, float change) {
139        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(end),
140                ys = (s & 0xFF), cws = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, cms = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s >>> 24 & 0xFE,
141                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
142        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + change * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
143                | (((int) (cws + change * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
144                | (((int) (cms + change * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
145                | (((int) (as + change * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
146    }
147
148    /**
149     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the
150     * alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
151     * as from {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} or
152     * {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
153     * end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is, both could be produced using IPT_HQ, or both
154     * could be produced using YCwCm, but not a mix of the two. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
155     * Colors.
156     * @param start the starting color as a packed float; alpha will be preserved
157     * @param end the target color as a packed float; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
158     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
159     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
160     */
161    public static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(final float start, final float end, float change) {
162        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(end),
163                ys = (s & 0xFF), cws = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, cms = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s >>> 24 & 0xFE,
164                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF;
165        change *= (e >>> 25) * 0.007874016f;
166        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + change * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
167                | (((int) (cws + change * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
168                | (((int) (cms + change * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
169                | as);
170    }
171
172    /**
173     * Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1. All colors should use the same color space.
174     * This is the same as calling {@link #lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} with a change of 0.5.
175     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
176     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
177     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
178     */
179    public static float mix(float color0, float color1) {
180        return lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f);
181    }
182
183    /**
184     * Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2. All colors should use the same color space.
185     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
186     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
187     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
188     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
189     */
190    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2) {
191        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f);
192    }
193
194    /**
195     * Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3. All colors should use the same color space.
196     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
197     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
198     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
199     * @param color3 the fourth color to mix, as a packed float color
200     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
201     */
202    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2, float color3) {
203        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f), color3, 0.25f);
204    }
205
206    /**
207     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
208     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
209     * @param colors an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
210     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
211     */
212    public static float mix(float... colors) {
213        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0)
214            return 0f; // transparent, usually
215        float result = colors[0];
216        for (int i = 1; i < colors.length; i++) {
217            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / (i + 1f));
218        }
219        return result;
220    }
221
222    /**
223     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
224     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
225     * This is mostly useful in conjunction with {@link com.badlogic.gdx.utils.FloatArray}, using its {@code items}
226     * for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its {@code size} for size.
227     * @param colors an array of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
228     * @param offset the index of the first item in {@code colors} to use
229     * @param size how many items from {@code colors} to use
230     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
231     */
232    public static float mix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
233        if(colors == null || colors.length < offset + size || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
234            return 0f; // transparent, usually
235        float result = colors[offset];
236        for (int i = offset + 1, o = offset + size, denom = 2; i < o; i++, denom++) {
237            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / denom);
238        }
239        return result;
240    }
241
242}
